answers: The API Compendium details methodologies for the natural gas and oil industry segments to consistently estimate direct GHG emissions over the entire value chain.
The greenhouse gasses focused on in the API Compendium are carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), and nitrous oxide (N2O).
The main focus of the ESRS E1 standard is Climate change.
The final rule is effective January 17, 2025.
The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) requires the EPA to impose and collect an annual charge on methane emissions.
The Australian Government will conduct a review of climate disclosure requirements in 2028-29.
The Treasury Laws Amendment (Financial Market Infrastructure and Other Measures) Act 2024 mandates climate-related financial disclosures.
AASB S1 General Requirements for Disclosure of Sustainability-related Financial Information and AASB S2 Climate-related Disclosures.

For reports issued between 1 July 2025 and 30 June 2028, only the regulator will be able to bring action relating to breaches of relevant provisions made in disclosures of scope 3 emissions and climate-related forward-looking statements.
The remedies available to the regulator will be limited to injunctions and declarations during this period.
40 CFR Part 98 Subpart C pertains to General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources.
40 CFR Part 98 Subpart LL pertains to Suppliers of Coal-based Liquid Fuels.
40 CFR Part 98 Subpart MM defines the source category as petroleum refineries and importers and exporters of petroleum products and natural gas liquids.
40 CFR Part 98 Subpart NN covers Suppliers of Natural Gas and Natural Gas Liquids.
Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities must report emissions only if emission sources specified in ยง 98.232(c) emit 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent or more per year.
CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions must be reported under 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart W.

Offshore petroleum and natural gas production is any platform structure, affixed temporarily or permanently to offshore submerged lands, that houses equipment to extract hydrocarbons from the ocean or lake floor and that processes and/or transfers such hydrocarbons to storage, transport vessels, or onshore.
No, 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart W does not include reporting emissions from offshore drilling and exploration that is not conducted on production platforms.
